36458502.review:
Can One Cereal Box Video Game Sway the Political Leanings of an Entire Generation? – the Pajama Sam Effect

     Humongous Entertainments’ 2000 point and click adventure game “Pajama Sam 3: You Are What You Eat from Your Head to Your Feet” is nothing short of a masterpiece. Through a complex and layered narrative, the player is guided through child-friendly lessons on nutrition and anatomy, with the added dimensions of allusions to geopolitical conflict, diplomatic relations, freedom of expression, the complexities of the legal and penal systems, as well as to the Marxist master-slave dialectic fundamental to the capitalist mode of production.

     This is made absolutely evident in one of the opening scenes of the game: our protagonist finds himself in the candy-cane jail, to await trial which is set for the next month; an obvious symbol for the consistent failures of the justice system, due in no small part to its bureaucratic inefficiencies. Sharing his jail cell is a broccoli named Florette, a delegate for the food group peace conference (a not-so-subtle allusion to the United Nations) who is being held as political prisoner. Florette asks our protagonist to help her escape imprisonment, and to rescue the other delegates so they may safely reach the peace conference. Clearly, the antagonistic Sweet State has as motive to keep the delegates (each representing an essential food group) away from the conference so as to maintain a nutritional hegemony without sanction. 
In the much cited section on estranged labour in Marx's 1844 Manuscripts, he posits four dimensions of alienation suffered by the proletarian class as a result of the capitalist system: alienation from the object of production, from the sum-total of labour activities, from his species-being, and most importantly, from fellow men. Following the fourth dimension of alienation of man from man, workers see other people the same way they see their own labour; as being alien to them, and therefore hostile. In PS3 (Pajama Sam 3), our hero must free the delegate Bean #47 trapped atop a girder in a quarry, overlooking a workers uprising due to internal factionalism between the Jelly Beans and the Kidney Beans. This conflict is orchestrated and clearly a result of greed and negligence on the part of the foreman, who represents the capitalist bourgeois proprietor of the means of production. This section of the game is a not-so-veiled representation of this fourth dimension of alienation. The Jelly Beans and the Kidney Beans see each other in the same light that they their own labour: they are estranged from it, and therefore confront it with hostility. When spoken to, the foreman shows little regard for the plight of his workers, but rather claims repeatedly that he has counted them, while shuffling through a number of blank documents; he is putting up a front of a caring boss, but his reluctance to provide any useful information until the third interraction with Pajama Sam shows that his care is only on a very superficial level, and that he still sees his workers in terms of their commodity values, and means to an end.

     One by one, the player then helps Pajama Sam find and save the other delegates and sends them on their way to the conference. In the final scene of the game, the six delegates, all in the peace conference (strongly resembling the United Nations Security Council), begin to bicker and argue with each other over which food group is better, rather than continuing deliberation with decorum. In response to this, Pajama Sam gives a rousing speech in which he implores the delegates to remember the original spirit of diplomacy between food groups: to address the concerns of human physiology, and to ensure their continued prosperity and collective autonomy.

     Many children across north America that enjoyed the many Kellogg's breakfast cereals that included the game in one of their boxes was then exposed to the leftist rhetoric overlaying the themes in PS3. Could these quasi-subliminal messages have influenced the political leanings of millenials? As was made evident from the last presidential election in the United States with the overwhelming support for candidates like Bernie Sanders by youth, this could very much be the case. The evidence points to this, and given the right statistical analysis of distribution and demograpgics related to PS3 and its players, it can be claimed that this is all due to the Pajama Sam effect.

34552226.review: The Pajama Sam series holds an important place in the Humungous Four. Each of the four main Humungous Entertainment franchises is aimed at a slightly different narrow age bracket - kids grow up so fast, after all. Putt-Putt is the youngest - essentially games about a bunch of living toys, be they vehicles, aliens or animals - and next is Freddi Fish, essentially a serties of interactive direct-to-video movies. Skipping ahead, Spy Fox is for kids old enough to know what it's parodying through pop-culture osmosis. And in between, when kids are just starting to wise up to things, is the Blue Calvin himself, Pajama Sam. But given how his personality has been tweaked relative to Calvin's, it would be better to say that this game is FOR Calvin. This game has real wits and brains behind it - not surprising, given that Ron Gilbert was behind it. This is one of those few works enjoyed by kids and adults for exactly the same reasons.

Benim gibi oyunu 40-50 defa bitirince replikleri bile ezberliyorsunuz. 1.5-2 saatte bitirebileceğiniz küçük yaş gruplarına hitap eden bir bulmaca oyunu. Gayet eğlenceli, odadaki çoğu eşya tıklanabilir, oyunun hikayesiyle alakası olmasa da tabağa tıkladığınızda içinden ufak bir kurabiyenin çıkıp dans etmesi istemsizce gülmenize neden olabiliyor. 33063041.review: Unlike with Freddi Fish, which was my favourite franchise as a kid, I've first encountered Pajama Sam not long ago and was immediately charmed by its great art and the very idea of a young kid who travels through the worlds of his imagination, always based on the most recent events in his life. After playing the games I can only say - what a shame that I didn't have them as a kid! I'm positive I would fall in love with them, because they have everything you want from a kids' game - a good message, funny and memorable characters (especially Sam who's just the cutest kid ever), an environment you can interact with, minigames and, surprisingly, very smart sense of humour. If you have children, I stongly recommend that you play Pajama Sam series with them, and if not - just try it yourself, it may very well return you to your own childhood. It sure did that for me.

30255310.review:
PS3: YAWYEFYHTYF is by in a way the greatest edutainment video game available on the market. It has comedy, it has tragedy, it has puzzles, it has skiing minigames. PS3: YAWYEFYHTYF offers all of the benefits of tactical role playing game, without all the fuss. Humungous Entertainment has proven their mastery of turn-based combat and any fan of series such as Tales, Shim Megami Tensei, Final Fantasy, or the Xeno series, ought to add this to their wish list and maybe even pick up the whole collection on sale. 

I cannot recommend you start with PS3: YAWYEFYHTYF, since PS: TNNTHWIDO has some required backstory for understanding the nuances of Sam's excursion inside of his pantry. Any reader of Marx or Engels should pick this game up. Think you know Friedrich Nietzsche, think again.

28682282.review:
Not my favorite but colorful all the same. As the games progress, they really do get hard and the map in this one was HUGE (or felt huge). It was a little difficult, but as with anything, you do something enough times and you'll be fine. I'm not the biggest fan of how they laid out the body (the eyes were surprisingly far from the brain) and how they portayed the whole argument of the food pyramid but it worked. I actually liked the lesson Sam learns. Very redeeming and very true.

The biggest plus of this game was 

One: We get to meet our favorite orange friend again
Two: We get to go on another crazy Pajama Sam adventure
Three: The writers of this game didn't get too preachy about eating right. They didn't make fruits and vegetables superior to the other groups and that's a good thing. It all comes together at the end with Sam's lesson even though the game as a whole seems scattered and jumbled.

If you liked the first two games then it's your duty to give this one a try. It's good, but not memorable. Not like the first two. Also, the end credits grace us with some rather interesting pictures. It's the 21st century and Pajama Sam offers a particularly eye-opening photo with our favorite orange friend. It made me tip a hat to the game makers. I never realized how progressive these games were until I became an adult. 

Well done.

22873014.review:
That was pretty good. I'm glad Humongous got back on track for Pajama Sam.

I don't think companies should stick to a solid formula if they create a franchise. Nintendo has managed to evolve the Mario franchise over the years, but with very few distinct changes. That's honestly one of the biggest problems with series. How far do you go to make a sequel distinct and different, while also keeping the same general formula of your previous installment(s)? 

I think Pajama Sam 3 did alright. I liked what it did. It was different, but it was still distinctly a Pajama Sam.

The story is similar to the other installments, where Sam has a problem and some supernatural imaginative event carries Sam to a separate world where he learns the error of his ways. Although, this is the first time in the series where Sam doesn't deal with a fear: it's more or less a personal flaw of overeating.

The world, much like the Land of Darkness from the first game, is incredibly imaginative. It's a massive rendition of Sam's body, as he goes around and "restores balance" to the food groups. There's no B.S, random conflict that comes out of nowhere. No random World Wide Weather business complex. It's simple imagination- like the first Pajama Sam.

But, despite what good things there are, there are still plenty of bad things. The mini-games are absolutely awful. I hate the bean-sorting game and the ski slopes. And some puzzles were a little vague, especially if the game was made for kids. Like specifically finding the sand castle for the bag to fill for the Cheese Delegate guy. And, the voice actress for Florette the Broccoli sounds like she's just reading a paper in front of her face.

However, the game follows the original Pajama Sam formula, without using the first game as a crutch, like Pajama Sam 2 did. It tells a new story with new characters, while keeping the charm, subtle humor, small symbolism, and story of personal growth that the original game created. And I enjoyed the time I spent playing it. I'm giving this one a 7/10.

22562096.review:
When I found out recently that Pajama Sam 3 is on steam, I immediately bought it as I can finally complete the game as I was not able to when I was a kid. It gave me a chance to finally have a closure to one of my favourite childhood game.

Throughout the game, it gave me a very nostalgic feeling as we've been constantly playing games of high graphical quality, contrasting a lot with the graphics of games used in the 2000, making me enjoy every moment of it. 

Even though this game is recommended to kids of ages 3-8, it doesn't seem that way as I'm sure that there are many adults here that would like to ride the nostalgia train and enjoy the game like how we used to when we were kids. Playing it as an adult sometimes surprises me at times as I remembered completing a particular stage of the game as a kid, but was stuck at it for a while when replaying it as an adult. I'm proud that I've not succumbed to the temptation of reading guides when I'm stucked since guides of any games are so readily available everywhere on the internet now. I mean, there ain't many guides when I was a kid and I almost completed the game. Even if there is, I doubt I know how to surf the internet at that age. 

To those that have played the game before as a kid, but have never completed it before, or simply just want to play the game for nostalgic purposes, it is worth every penny to buy the game.

17511517.review: In the year 2000, while some people were playing games like Counter-Strike, the real hardcore gamers – my five-year old self included – were playing Pajama Sam 3. Every time our ignorant parents would accuse us of rotting our brains away by playing video games, we could point to the latest Pajama Sam title and show how we were teaching ourselves about balanced nutrition and international negotiations simultaneously in Sam’s latest adventure. Pajama Sam 3 is as good as it gets: featuring a quest to unite all the food groups and prevent total war (take notes, world leaders: diplomacy does work), a sidequest to collect enough box tops to win a Pajama Man action figure (does anyone else remember collecting these for school fundraisers as a kid?) and a cameo of everyone’s favorite hippie anarchist carrot (the diehard Pajama Sam fans will go crazy for this one), Pajama Sam 3: You Are What You Eat From Your Head to Your Feet is a masterpiece from beginning to end. Even if you aren’t a lifelong Pajama Sam fan and can’t experience a jolt of nostalgia like everyone else, you at least owe it to yourself to play Pajama Sam 3 today so you can at least pretend to be as cool as we were fifteen years ago.

15364761.review: In the third installment of the Pajama Sam series, Sam eats his way through several boxes of cookies in order to collect the right amount of box tops in exchange for a Pajama Man action figure. Right when he opens the final box, all of the cookies come jumping out and storm into the kitchen. Sam knows they were up to no good and decides to trial them as "Pajama Sam". Upon entering the kitchen Sam soon enters yet another world of his imagination inside the kitchen storage room which is a gateway to a food world. All six food groups of the world aren't in peace with each other and the only ones who can stablize peace are the food delicates of each food group. It's up to Sam to prevent a war from breaking out. Unlike in the previous two games, Sam isn't over coming any fears in this game, instead it's about preventing war and learning about the food groups as he progresses his mission. The story is just as inventive as the previous installments and the characters and jokes once again are clever and well thought out. If you love the last two Pajama Sam games, then you can't go wrong with this one.

13552616.review:
Pajama Sam 3: You Are What You Eat From Your Head To Your Feet – Raymond K. Turcotte

This game is a brain twister; you must use your head, but also have common scene. I remember playing this game and not know what to do. Until thinking of the obvious. I totally recommended this game to every crowed! Adult or child. You’ll have fun!

If your child has played beginning level software and is ready to move on to more advanced gameplay, Humongous Entertainment's Pajama Sam series (and Freddie Fish and Putt-Putt as well) are an excellent choice. These titles take the cognitive tasks up a notch as children must accumulate specific items, navigate a number of locations, and use their problem-solving skills to help new friends and achieve larger goals. Along the way, funny and lovable Pajama Sam will meet a number of nice characters, visit a variety of interesting locations and play mini-games as he completes the larger task of getting a representative of each food group out of a pickle so they can get to an important meeting. Along the way he will solve a lot of smaller puzzles and click on many objects that dance or act out funny events. Specifics change if you start a new game, and you will want to play with your child a few times before they'll be able to enjoy it on their own, so each game is good for hours of fun.

This is an awesome little point and click game that's almost, if not just as, good as the first Pajama Sam game. You Are What You Eat is encourages you to scan enviroments for items and utilize your imagination in solving problems. 

The game is effectively an interactive cartoon in which the plotline is basically about talking food attending a Peace Conference in their equivelant of the United Nations. Nearly everything in the background is interactive, with neat and somewhat trippy little animations hidden amongst bushes and behind signs.

Oh, the nostalgia... This was the only Pajama Sam game that I never got a chance to play growing up. I could have done the demo with my eyes shut, but I never got to play the actual game. That said, when I saw that this was on Steam, I was ecstatic.
I will say, I don't think that this is quite as good as the original Pajama Sam, but that could be the fault of my rose-colored nostalgia glasses. Even so, this is still a worthy addition to the Pajama Sam series, and a fun point-and-click puzzle game for the kids.

11076429.review:
Our protagonist, Pajama Sam, is about to finish the last cookie box for his favorite action figure. As he reaches for the last box, a familiar voice calls out. "Sam, it's time for dinner!" Not feeling quite hungry for a meal, Sam notices something strange. The cookies come to life! As they flee, Sam searches for a logical place - the pantry. The door shuts, trapping Pajama Sam into a world full of scrumptious sweets, delectable delights, and tasty treats.

You play as Sam, a little boy looking to stop the general from declaring war. How does Sam do this? He needs to find members of each food group so they can hold a conference together. The only problem is...they've gone missing! Pajama Sam will need to consume candy canes to escape prison, drive on a donut, resolve balance between beans, and much more. The cool thing about this game (and the other Humongous Entertainment games) is that your second gameplay might be different than the first. The different food groups might be in different places next time, so replay value is actually fun.

I loved the creativity put forth in this game. Foods  of all sorts come to life with memorable personalities.
-Strong, beefy muffins draw cupcakes on the coast. 
-Candy canes substitute jail bars.
-The names. Plums nicknamed "plummers." A granny smith apple named Granny Smythe. The sweet troops marching around.

Fans who have not played this game yet will love the cameo appearances. The carrot from the first Pajama Sam game makes a return. There's also Sprinkles the Donut who helps Sam travel. (It reminds me from Otto from PS1). 

Not only is this a fun game, the name is definitely true. Sam makes a valid point at the end of the adventure. You are what you eat from your head to your feet.

10547095.review:
If you like playing games about a blue alien kid with Bobby Hill's voice going on an acid trip though a land made out of french fries, amusement parks, and a giant human heart that's powered by sorting beans, you will like this game.

A pure nostalgia trip, plain and simple. Game is a lot shorter than I remember, but that might be because the last time I played it I was 7 years old. Still fun though, puzzles are neat. A lot of detail went in to the artwork and there's a billion little "easer egg" things to click on and watch some short animations. I didn't even know there were different ways to play through the game, the endings are the same but the story is randomized, which is cool for a 14 year old game.

There might be some replayability but like I said the game is short, like an hour or so per play.

39994795.review:
Pajama Sam 3: You Are What You Eat From Your Head to Your Feet, or PJS3: YAWYEFYHTYF for short is a beautiful meditation on what it means to be human, the struggles of compromise, and the complexities of global multi-party politics.
In this game you play as the titular Pajama Sam; the alter ego of Sam, who goes on grandiose adventures, which are speculated to occur entirely in his imagination, in order to fix some problem in his waking life. In PJS3: YAWYEFYHTYF Sam is facing the pressing issue of invasive consumerism, as he's pushed to eat 20 boxes of cookies in one sitting in order to acquire enough box tops to get a prize of his role model, Pajama Man. This excursion ends up ruining his appetite for supper, this is then paralleled in the game by Pajama Sam eating a giant cake and being forced to pay the consequences by being thrown in prison. In this allegory for his actions Pajama Sam (not to be mistaken with the non-imaginary "Sam") Must seek out and rescue all of the delegates for the peace council, who have all become incopacitated in some way, Luke Wigglebig not included. This small detail makes me believe that the candy people were attempting to prolong the war by delaying the delegates, in order to cement candy as the one true food group.The first delagate you find is your prisonmate, Florette the Broccoli who was arrested due to Anarchistic Insurection. The second you find is Piérre le Pain of the grain peoples, who is found on top of the Ferris wheel, being humiliated by the muffins who used to be his friends, however they have a separate agenda and would rather follow their art careers than help ensure the peace of their people. Later on you find a race war breaking out between the Jelly Beans and the Kidney Beans and the quarry, because although they are both beans, the only thing that matters is the colour of their outsides. This causes them to stop working and partition themselves, with the Bean Foreman being powerless to stop the conflict, Pajama Sam ends up using circular logic to convince them to argue the opposite side's point without realization. This causes the agression to simmer down, and allows Bean #47 to attend the peace council without fear of being jumped by the local Jelly Bean gangs. The next delagate we run into is Granny Smyth of the fruits, who is being harassed by a group of unrepresented canned goods, in order to passify this group you need to promise funded community programs. This convinces the canned goods to free Granny Smyth, allowing her to go to the peace council. The final delagate you find is Chuck "Cheese of Adventure" Cheddar, who's flee via hot air balloon was halted by becoming lodged in the cotton candy clouds (who were possibly working for the candy kingdom), preventing him from leaving the country. You will end up blackmailing him, that if you save him from dying, by dislodging the hot air balloon that he'd be required to go to the peace council, which he accepts. With all the delegates rounded up, the negotiations descend into chaos, with all sides becoming more entrenched in their positions, while also yelling slurs at the other delegates and attempting to discredit their positions. It seems as if peace is impossible, until Pajama Sam chimes in as a neutral 3rd party, convincing them of equal representation in an oligarchy style food government. The game ends with Pajama Sam snapping out of his sugar-induced fever dream and remembering that it was time for Dinner.
